questions.question: If you had invited her, she ...................................... with us.
questions.description: When the verb in the if-clause is in the past perfect tense, we use would / could have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If I .......................... the opportunity, I would have gone to university.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we need a past participle in the if-clause.

questions.question: If I ............................. her number, I would call her.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If you take this medication, you ................................. well.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If you had sold your home then, you .............................. rich now.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If you ate your breakfast, you ................................ not be hungry now.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If you ............................ me, we both would have been happy.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If you spoke a foreign language, you ............................... a better job.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: I could marry her if I ............................ to.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If your computer ........................... you will lose unsaved work.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If I am late, my father .......................... me to school.
questions.description: In the zero conditional, we use a simple present tense in both clauses.

questions.question: If you behaved more politely, they .............................. help you.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would/ could/ might + infinitive in the main clause.
